# Draft:Ancient Kurundi Viharaya

----
The Ancient Kurundi viharaya (), also known as Kurundavāshoka viharaya historically, is a Sinhalese Buddhist temple  built by King Khallātanāga in Mulle duwa (Mullaitivu) during the region of 110 B.C to 103, this is also the place where Kurundi Atthakathā was compiled also the site where Gautama Buddha journeyed through Sri Lanka for the 2nd time.
History
The Ancient Kurundi viharaya was mentioned in the Mahawansa and was credited to King Khallātanāga of the Kingdom of Anuradhapura.
Later successors of King Khallātanāga conducted various works near the site, including King Aggabodi I who built a tank known as the Kurunda wapi and a coconut field. The minister of the King also has said to have given offering to the viharaya.
In the Polonnaruwa period the monarch mentioned as King Vijayabahu I restored the viharaya since its construction.
According to the Archaelogist Cyril Nicholas a residence for the resting of monks was built in the name of Kurundacullaka near the viharaya.}}

Many Buddhist temples in the north and east has been vandalized, destroyed or turned into kovils by the later Tamil residents.
Modern day issue
Buddhist monks and residents of north was forced to leave due to unrest created in the area by Tamil extremists due to Tamil nationalism around the late century.
North of Sri Lanka was unable to enter due to LTTE occupation and after the war was over, the archaeological department resurveyed the area and in 2013 the site was declared as a protected archaeological site but in 2018 the archaeological department and the TNA (political party) with some locals came into a dispute regarding the site, which they claimed the site was a Siva temple and had threatened the Buddhist priest and other workers from the archaeological department and they were able to temporarily stop any works in the site by filing a complaint to the Mullaitivu court by claiming any further excavations in the site will lead to a unrest among the citizens in the north of Sri Lanka.
Before the end of 2020 the Mullaitivu court gave permission to the archaeological department to continue their work and around 2021 completing of the conservation of the viharaya was planned but during the placing of Buddhist relics in the viharaya was disturbed by TNA and some locals into the site by claiming it as their “Homeland” and this site is actually a “Ancient Hindu kovil.”
In 2023 the archaeological department declared 229 acres surrounding the viharaya to be considered to be part of the kurundi archaeological site giving a total acres of 400, since archaeological artifacts have been found in these places, again the archaeological work was blocked by locals claiming that Sivalingam and a Hindu deity that was worshipped by the locals were taken away by archeological department workers.
Archaeologist and a monk, Venerable Ellawala Medhananda Thera declined the claims of the locals that the surrounding area of the viharaya was paddy lands and the Tamil locals had harvested before the war which is further supported by the past archeological surveys done in the site.
